speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon, everyone.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To begin, I’d like to say a few words about Paul Volcker, who, as you know, passed away earlier this week.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Paul Volcker served as Federal Reserve Chair from 1979 to 1987.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: He accomplished many things during his long and distinguished career at the Fed and elsewhere.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, he’s best known for leading the fight to tame the double-digit inflation that he inherited as Chair, thus laying the foundation for the prosperity and price stability we enjoy today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But what is perhaps most admirable about him—more than his many accomplishments—was his character.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: He believed that there is no higher calling than public service, and he dedicated the lion’s share of his life to it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With courage, integrity, and tenacity, he always pursued the policies that he believed would ultimately benefit all Americans.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I continue to draw inspiration from his example.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Turning to today’s meeting, my colleagues and I decided to leave our policy rate unchanged after lowering it a total of ¾ percentage point at the previous three meetings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As always, we base our decisions on judgment of how best to achieve the goals Congress has given us: maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our economic outlook remains a favorable one despite global developments and ongoing risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With our decisions through the course of the past year, we believe that monetary policy is well positioned to serve the American people by supporting continued economic growth, a strong job market, and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic expansion is in its 11th year, the longest on record.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Household spending has been strong, supported by a healthy job market, rising incomes, and solid consumer confidence.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In contrast, business investment and exports remain weak, and manufacturing output has declined over the past year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As has been the case for some time, sluggish growth December 11, 2019 abroad and trade developments have been weighing on those sectors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even so, the overall Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL economy has been growing moderately.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And with a strong household sector and supportive monetary and financial conditions, we expect moderate growth to continue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As seen from FOMC participants’ most recent projections, the median expectation for real GDP growth slows slightly over the next few years but remains near 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate has been near half-century lows for well more than a year, and the pace of job gains remains solid.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Participation in the labor force by people in their prime working years, ages 25 through 54, has been increasing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And wages have been rising, particularly for lower-paying jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People who live and work in low- and middle-income communities tell us that many who have struggled to find work are now finding new opportunities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Employment gains have been broad based across all racial and ethnic groups and all levels of education.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These developments underscore for us the importance of sustaining the expansion so that the strong job market reaches more of those left behind.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect the job market to remain strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median of participants’ projections for the unemployment rate remains below 4 percent over the next several years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation continues to run below our symmetric 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the 12 months through October, total PCE inflation was 1.3 percent, and core inflation—which excludes volatile food and energy prices and is a better indicator of future inflation—was 1.6 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While low and stable inflation is certainly a good thing, inflation that runs persistently below our objective can lead to an unhealthy dynamic in which longer-term inflation expectations drift down, pulling actual inflation even lower.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In turn, interest rates would be lower as well and closer to their effective lower bound.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As a result, the scope for interest rate reductions to support the economy in a future downturn would be diminished, resulting in worse economic outcomes December 11, 2019 for American families and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Against the backdrop of a strong economy and supportive Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL monetary policy, we expect inflation will rise to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median of participants’ projection rises to 1.9 percent next year and 2 percent in 2021.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re strongly committed to achieving our symmetric 2 percent inflation goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the course of the past year, our views about the path of interest rates that would best achieve our employment and inflation objectives changed significantly, as the economy faced some important challenges from weaker global growth and trade developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the year progressed, we adjusted the stance of monetary policy to cushion the economy from these developments and to provide some insurance against the associated risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, inflation pressures were unexpectedly muted, strengthening the case for a more supportive stance of policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Rather than modestly increasing the target rate for the federal funds rate this year, as seemed appropriate a year ago, we reduced it by ¾ percentage point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This shift has helped support the economy and has kept the outlook on track.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The medians of participants’ projections for economic growth, the unemployment rate, and inflation are little changed from a year ago, aside from a lower inflation projection for 2019.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, that is the function of monetary policy—to adjust interest rates to promote employment and price stability in response to forces acting on the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We believe that the current stance of monetary policy will support sustained growth, a strong labor market, and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As long as incoming information about the economy remains broadly consistent with this outlook, the current stance of monetary policy likely will remain appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking ahead, we will be monitoring the effects of our recent policy actions, along with other information bearing on the outlook, as we assess the appropriate path of the target range for the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, if December 11, 2019 developments emerge that cause a material reassessment of our outlook, we would respond Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL accordingly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Policy is not on a preset course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Finally, I wanted to note that we’ve been purchasing Treasury bills and conducting repurchase operations, consistent with the plan we announced in December.1 These technical operations are aimed at maintaining an ample level of reserves and addressing money market pressures that could adversely affect the implementation of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our operations have gone well so far; pressures in money markets over recent weeks have been subdued.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To address possible pressures in money markets over the year-end, we’ve been conducting term repo operations spanning year-end.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We stand ready to adjust the details of our operations as appropriate to keep the federal funds rate in the target range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you, and I’ll be happy to take your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, that’s—what’s happening there is the fact that the relationship between resource utilization, or unemployment, and inflation has just gotten weaker and weaker over the years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you go back 50 years, you would have seen that, when there was—when labor markets were tight and unemployment was low, inflation moved right up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then as the Fed got control of inflation, the connection got weaker and weaker and weaker, to the point where there’s still a connection, but it’s—it’s a very faint one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I—what that suggests is that you 1 Chair Powell intended to say the repurchase operations were announced in October.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: December 11, 2019 would need to keep policy somewhat accommodative.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we believe that policy is somewhat Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL accommodative, and we think that that’s the appropriate place for policy to be in order to drive up inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I don’t think that’s right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, we—the—again, the relationship between slack in the economy and inflation is weak, has been weak.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The coefficient is something like 0.1.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s much, much lower than it used to be, but I don’t know that it’s gone down any more in the last decade.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It just is quite faint.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s still there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, you can see it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look—look at where wages were three or four years ago, they were running around 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And now the whole group of different wage measures that we monitor has moved up to 3 and 3½ percent, and that suggests tightening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The same thing is true, but much less true, of inflation, the relationship between—in a way, the wage Phillips curve has a higher coefficient than the price Phillips curve does.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we do still see some relationship, and that’s what you’re seeing in those numbers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s similarities, conceptual similarities, I think, between the two instances during that long expansion, I guess in ’95 and ’98, when the Fed cut three times only to resume raising rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s the same situation we believe we’re in here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this is that we did, in fact, turn out to do three rate cuts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That wasn’t in the plan, you know, in any kind of specific way at the beginning.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s the same.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What’s different is, you have a very different—you have very different structural characteristics in the economy, particularly around inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So now, as you can see, inflation is barely moving up, notwithstanding that unemployment is at 50-year lows and expected to remain there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the need for rate increases is less.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, this is—it’s a good thing that, you know, we think we can—I think we’ve learned that unemployment can remain at quite low levels for an extended period of time without unwanted upward pressure on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, we need some upward pressure on inflation to get back to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s quite different in ’95 and ’98 when there were those two adjustments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I would say, similarities and differences.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’m going to take a little step back, and I will—I will get to your specific questions on the year-end and on T-bills.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess I want to start by stressing that these are very important operational matters but that are not likely to have any macroeconomic implications.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’d decided back in January to remain an ample-reserves regime, and that means we will be setting the federal funds rate—the range for the federal funds rate through our administered rates and not through active management of the level of reserves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re committed to robustly implementing that framework, as you can see by our actions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the purpose of all this, let’s remember, is to assure that our monetary policy decisions will be transmitted to the federal funds rate, which in turn affects other short-term rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have the tools to accomplish that, and we will use them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The purpose of all this is not to eliminate all volatility, particularly in the repo market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, taking you back, this—as you know, we had very gradually allowed the balance sheet to shrink, we slowed that gradual pace by half in March, and then we ended it in July.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And yet we saw, actually, in September that reserves—the markets acted as though reserves had become scarce.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So what had happened was that liquidity, which actually existed, didn’t flow into the repo market, and that had effects on the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: December 11, 2019 And we’ve been very carefully looking at the reasons why that might have happened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL are—there are payments issues, there have been a number of supervisory and regulatory issues raised—we’re looking carefully at those.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re open to ideas for modifying supervisory and regulatory practice in ways that don’t undermine safety and soundness, and a number of ideas are under—under examination there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To go through it sort of by—in time, we started off, really, on September 17 with overnight operations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: By October 11 we had created and put into effect a plan.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That plan is in effect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think, for the last couple of months, repo markets have been functioning well, short-term rates are stable, markets are functioning.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you asked about year-end.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Temporary upward pressures on short-term money market rates are not unusual around year-end.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And our—both our repo operations and Treasury bill purchases are intended to mitigate the risks that such pressures pose to our control of the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think that the pressures appear manageable, and we stand ready to adjust the details of our operations as necessary to keep the federal funds rate in the target range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our strategy has been—essentially, the key to our strategy is to supply reserves in the near term through—through both overnight and term repo, and, at the same time, we’re raising the underlying level of reserves through bill purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ll take that now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve said bills—bill purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve also said that we were willing to adapt our strategy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not at this place, but if it does become appropriate for us to purchase other short-term coupon securities, then we would be prepared to do that if—if the need arises.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—but we don’t—we don’t—we’re not in that place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It looks—it very much looks like the bill—so those bill purchases are going well, just according to expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, the other thing I’ll say is that we’re in, you know, very regular contact with market participants all the time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be December 11, 2019 providing—we’ll be continuing that, and we’re prepared to adjust our tactics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re—we’re Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL focused on—on year-end as well and prepared to adjust our operations as appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on the standing repo facility, as you know, we’ve actually had a couple of meetings where we’ve discussed that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the standing repo facility is something that’ll take some time to evaluate and create the parameters of and put into place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the moment what we’re focused on is, you know—we’re now focused on year-end.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I should also mention that after the year-end, the sense of it is that as the underlying level of reserves moves up because of bill purchases, as that happens, there will come a time when it will be appropriate for overnight and term repo to gradually decline.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t know—we can’t know today what the timing of that will be, but that’s the way—that’s the way we see it going over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, as I mentioned, actually, at the last press conference, we think our policy rate is appropriate and will remain appropriate as long as incoming data are broadly in keeping with our—with our outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And in order to move rates up, I would want to see inflation that’s persistent and that’s significant—a significant move-up in inflation that’s also persistent before raising rates to address inflation concerns.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s my view.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t—we haven’t tried to turn it into some sort of, you know, official forward guidance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It happens to be my view that that’s what it would take to want to move interest rates up in order to deal with inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think what you’re seeing is, you’ve got a full year of the median being flat, which is, we think, accommodative, modestly accommodative, and inflation not moving up very much, as we’ve discussed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that underscores, I think, the challenge of getting inflation to move up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Committee has wanted inflation to be at 2 percent, squarely at 2 percent, for—ever since I arrived in 2012.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it hasn’t happened, and it’s just—it’s because there are disinflationary forces around the world, and they’ve been stronger than, I think, people understood them to be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of those out-year rate increases, what’s you’re—you’re looking at rate increases more than a year into the future, and, you know, people will have their own explanations for why they do that, but we—really, none of us have much of a sense of what the economy will be like in 2021.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think what may be behind some of that is just the thought that, over time, it would be appropriate—if you believe that the neutral rate is 2½ percent, it would be appropriate for your rates to move up in that direction.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will also say to you that a number of people wrote down, and you can’t see this at this level of detail, but—today—but a number of people did write down overshoots of inflation as appropriate—under appropriate policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, it’s just that there is still, empirically, by many, many different—by the work of many different analysts, there is a relationship between resource utilization, by which I mean unemployment, and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just relatively weak.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, that’s not a bad thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That means that we can run at low levels of unemployment and have a historically good—in some dimensions—labor market without having to worry about inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It also means, though, that it’s not easy to move inflation up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I would say there’s more humility than there is confidence in this at this point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s been very challenging to get inflation to be at target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look around the world, the United States, of all major economies, has been closest to it but still hasn’t quite been able to achieve it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would also point out that this year, which has been a good year for the economy, inflation—core inflation is actually running at 1.6 percent, whereas it ran close to 2 percent most of last year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s—it’s a real challenge, and—but I think we’re using our tools as best we can to meet that challenge.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I—you know, I think the answer to the question of whether saying it is enough to create credibility, the answer to that is “no.” And I think you have to back that up with policy that supports the outcome, and that’s what we’re trying to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so the—the changes that we’re looking at to the framework are—I think they take all of that on board, and—but they’re—what they’re—what they are designed to do is to strengthen the credibility of that—of that inflation target, but only if followed by policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Ultimately, it will take time to establish—to move inflation expectations up from where they are, which appears to be a bit below 2 percent, will not happen overnight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’ll have to happen over time as credibility is built.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the Fed has great inflation credibility, but inflation expectations are anchored at about their 25-year average, which is a few ticks below 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I did see the news today that it appears there’s an agreement to move forward to vote on USMCA, and, of course, it’s not our role to comment on particular trade policies or criticize them one way or the other or evaluate them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will say, though, that getting—if the deal were to be enacted, then it would certainly remove some of the trade policy December 11, 2019 uncertainty, and that would be, I believe, a positive for the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’ll say the same thing Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL about the negotiations with China, which haven’t reached that point yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve been hearing from our people that we talked to—the many, many people and businesses that we talked to in—through the Reserve Banks that wind up being written up in the Beige Book, and they’ve been telling us all year—for a year and a half, really, that trade policy uncertainty is weighing on the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I do think that, again, without commenting on it—in any way on the process or the content of the agreement, I think that uncertainty—removal of uncertainty around that would be a positive for the economy as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the—you know, the focus really is on how to use our strategies, tools, and communications to achieve both sides of the mandate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’re right, though, that we’ve talked here a lot about inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think that the—I think, more broadly, over a period of years—many years—we’ve been learning that the natural rate of unemployment is lower.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just been—it’s in estimates not just at the Fed, but among—broadly among economists—labor economists have seen that the connection—that we can sustain much lower levels of unemployment than had been thought.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, as I mentioned, that’s a good thing because that means we—we don’t have to worry so much about inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s—and you see the benefits of that in today’s labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I—you know, the Fed Listens events are about inflation to a much lesser extent than they are about maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you’ve—if you’ve listened to or attended any of those, the discussion—we always focus on inflation as well, but the discussion is really around what’s happening in low- and moderate-income communities and among small businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think you—you get a perspective, which—you know, we were already getting that from our extensive outreach to community groups and such.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it was help to get—helpful to get it in the context of a monetary policy review.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think that the fact that these communities have so much—such high levels of unemployment and low levels of labor force participation tells you that there is slack out there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think that does also inform our understanding of what we mean by “maximum employment.” And it’s been a very positive—I would say that the Fed Listens events have been—have been extraordinarily positive, and they’re certainly something we’ll repeat.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You also see from December 11, 2019 the business perspective that companies are taking all kinds of measures to—you know, to look Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL through things on people’s résumés that would have perhaps disqualified them in other kinds of environments, training is moving up—you hear just a lot—there are a lot of things going on that suggest that people at the margins of the labor force are being pulled in and being given chances, which is a great thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I—I think we have kind of internalized—and this isn’t—this isn’t news for today, this is something we’ve been saying for, you know, for several years—you’ve seen us moving down our estimates of the—of maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, it’s already—it’s already understood, I think, that—that there’s more—even though we’re at 3½ percent unemployment, there’s actually more slack out there, in a sense.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And—and the risks of, you know, using accommodative monetary policy, our tool, to explore that are relatively low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think we know that, and I think the review certainly underscores that, but that’s—that’s a very important insight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on Treasuries versus reserves, we’ve done a ton of work on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve talked to supervisors, and—it’s interesting, if you look at the banks, they’re all over the place on the composition of their—of their buffer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you have to have—you have a business model, and that business model suggests what your stress outflows will be, and that suggests what your buffer should be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you see them making quite different choices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Some of them have lots of reserves and, you know, fewer Treasuries, and then they change their mind and they switch, so it’s not obvious that there’s one thing happening there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Notwithstanding that, we have—we’ve gone out to try to understand that, talking to supervisors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the—the TGA, you know, we have not tried to pull the TGA into this yet; we’ve taken it as exogenous.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t know that at some point we won’t have those discussions, but, you know, Treasury—we want Treasury to be able to have the cash that it needs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then we should—we are essentially taking that as exogenous to our—to our work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, there may come a time when we—when we talk about that, but we haven’t done much of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think there is some of that, though—and so we’re working hard and fast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But those are things, you know, the—if they take rule changes, it’ll take, you December 11, 2019 know, a notice of public rulemaking—it’ll take three months and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those things Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL take time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These things that we’re working on now, though—like, you know, going through year-end with the overnight facilities and the bill purchases and the term repo—those are—those are things we have to do right now and are doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, we did, actually—if you look at the statement, you’ll notice that we—we did call out global developments and muted inflation pressures later in the statement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, those are the things that we’ve been monitoring all year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve put now in place policies that we think are appropriate to address those things, so we’re not revisiting that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But those are—those are just key things, and they haven’t gone away, so we thought it was appropriate to mention them there—still subject to the idea that, for us to change our stance, we would want to see a material reassessment of the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I mean, one thing that we’re mindful of is that we’ve cut rates three times since July.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s 75 basis points’ worth of cuts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we do believe that monetary December 11, 2019 policy operates with long and variable lags, and that it will take some time before the full effects Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL of those actions are seen in the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’ll take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s one reason to hold back and—and wait.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we thought—I think we took strong measures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, if you look at—more broadly at the Treasury yield curve, it has moved more than 75 basis points.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’ve—you’ve had quite a significant move in the direction of higher accommodation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of what’s—you know, what is material at the end of the day, well, I would just say, whether or not a change in the outlook merits a policy response will be a collective judgment of the FOMC.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There isn’t any single factor that will determine our decisions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll—we’ll look at a full range of data and other information bearing on the economic outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I—this wouldn’t be a—my response will not be about Paul Volcker, but—so, well, you started with Paul Volcker.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, if you look back at 2018—I’ll just take you back to the beginning of 2018.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We had an economy growing at 3 percent, we had inflation at 2 percent, and we had a trillion and a half dollars’ worth of stimulus arriving, and the federal funds rate was 1.4 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it wasn’t that—so we moved—we moved policy up during the course of the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We never got policy even at the level of what we thought the neutral rate was at the time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there was no sense of it being restrictive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We took steps to make it less accommodative, and that seemed to be the right thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It still seems to me to be the right thing in hindsight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The idea that we were trying to, you know, slow the economy down—we December 11, 2019 were really just trying to get near neutral.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And even with the last rate increase a year ago, we Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL were still meaningfully below the median estimate on the Committee of what the neutral rate was.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So policy was always accommodative during the course of that year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think what’s happened is, the—obviously, the facts on the ground have changed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You saw the global economic slowdown begin in the middle of last year, gather force, and then continue to go on this year, so you’ve seen a continual weakening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Just look at the IMF’s forecasts of growth from, you know, the spring of 2018 and compare them to now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’ve had quite a significant—that does affect us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think, also, the trade situation was just beginning in the middle of ’18, and I think it had—has had—you know, I think there’ll be a very, very wide range of estimates of the effect, but I think it’s had a meaningful effect on output just through the uncertainty channel and, to a lesser extent, through—through, you know, the tariff effects.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, that’s not to make a judgment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not up to us to make a judgment about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, that’s what—that would be my story.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I wouldn’t want to speculate on—on a hypothetical.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say—we’ll just have to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re—we look at a range of factors and we’ve—as I’ve said before, we try to look through the volatility in trade news and trade negotiations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We try not to react.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can’t react.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Monetary policy is not the right tool to react in the very short term to volatility and, you know, things that can change back and forth and back and forth as this has December 11, 2019 happened, as is probably typical of a—of a large complex negotiation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in terms of—you Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL know, I—again, I don’t want to get into hypothetical outcomes, though, if that’s all right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I—I’m going to stick with my and my predecessors’ longtime practice of not discussing private meetings with elected officials—or other officials, really.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t consider things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With—I think properly understood, it can be useful, but that’s been a challenge.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I think “properly understood” to me means looking at what it is and not at what it isn’t.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And what it is is, it’s an expression of the thinking about individual Committee members about appropriate monetary policy and the path of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Remember that we write all that down, and we send it in, and it gets compiled.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we don’t discuss it at the meeting, and we don’t negotiate a plan.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There is no—there’s no agreement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s no plan.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think, particularly at inflection points, it’s hard to convey the reality, which is that policy is always going to depend on the economic outlook and changes in the economic outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And when the economic outlook is changing, the dots are—they’re just not a consideration.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to do what we think is the right thing for the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if the fact—dots that we did six months ago or three months ago don’t agree with that, that’s not even in the conversation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So its more—but it can it be useful if—and I think—but, as I said, it’s been a challenge, and so I—I do—I do like to say, if you focus too much on the dots, you can—you can miss the broader picture.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me say, we’re—we’ve been working on this all year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re just at the stage where we’ve had a really interesting discussion about the various tools that we have at the October meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At this meeting, we talked about the way monetary policy affects different groups in the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we had a—we talked about the Fed Listens events and some very interesting research.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re just getting to the stage where we’re looking at conclusions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And those things—many of those things would wind up as changes, if you will, modifications to the “Statement of Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy.” I think that process will take until the middle December 11, 2019 of the year where—but we want to approach it very thoroughly and very carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that is— Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL in effect, that is our framework document.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I wouldn’t prejudge.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No one—I believe we will be able to—to reach a successful conclusion and make meaningful improvements.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of “4 percent”—so that’s—I think it’s premature for people to be saying that this isn’t going anywhere.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know—and if you define going anywhere as a 4 percent inflation target—let me talk about the 4 percent inflation target.

sentence: So I’ll go back to the point that just saying words is not itself credible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

sentence: So I think we—I think you need to lower your sights a little bit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I think it’s a fair question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, I think—I’d like for this review to come out with very—a set of positive results—you know, meaningful improvements.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It doesn’t mean it has to solve every problem going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want to—we want to have this be a successful exercise where we meaningfully improve our monetary policy framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These things don’t tend to move in—you know, in a lurchy way, they tend to evolve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think—and if we do this, then in a few years, again and again and things like that, then we can—at least we’re moving in a good direction.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think we will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m confident we will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, you know, I have to say, my total focus is on right now and getting policy right and thinking about next year—you know, thinking about what’s the economy December 11, 2019 going to be doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I like where we are on policy, as I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think our policy stance is Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL appropriate and likely to remain so as long as the outlook is broadly like this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know—I mean, it’s too long of a question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I don’t know how to get after that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s—there’s a lot of learning that comes into—from the economy every year and in the way we do our jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’re always going to be trying to learn lessons.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, wage gains have moved up a bit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look back three, four years, you’ll see wages are growing around 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now you see them moving up, you know, more at 3, 3½ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s a couple of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think there are a range of explanations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For instance, one would be that productivity has just been low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So wages should go up to cover inflation and productivity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Productivity has been low, and that—that is very likely to be holding back wages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I also think there are other December 11, 2019 possible potential explanations, such as, you know, globalization can be—the idea that you can Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL make, manufacture, or even provide services anywhere in the world to anywhere in the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that hangs over the wage-setting process—and everywhere, pretty much.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You don’t see—there isn’t the kind of traction in the wage market that—even in a tight labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Another thing is, though, that the labor market may not be as tight as we had thought it was.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, I think there—there are many, many possible explanations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will say, though, if you look, for example, at nonsupervisory employees in the labor report, there are—their wages are going up at 3.7 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so, you do see—and wages are going up the most for people at the lower end of the—that’s been true for the last couple of years—lower end of the wage spectrum.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you do see wages moving up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just—they’re not moving up at—at very high rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, at the end of the day, that probably has most to do with productivity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People were writing down numbers in the fives, and then they were writing down numbers in the fours.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And now, unemployment has been in the threes for a year and a half, and we still see wage inflation, as you mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The level of wage inflation has actually moved down, although, there may be compositional effects in that number that may—that may be, to some extent, about younger workers coming in at lower wages that—than retiring workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you wouldn’t—that shouldn’t have much of an effect, actually.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It may just be that there’s more slack in the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think we are seeing that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re December 11, 2019 seeing—really, it showed up through higher participation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For many years, we’ve thought that Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL there’s a trend decline in participation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Notwithstanding that, against that trend, we’ve seen prime-age participation moving up pretty steadily over the last two or three years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s a very positive thing, but it does sort of provide more labor supply, meaning a less tight labor market.

sentence: So, you know, we think the CRA—we know the CRA is a very important law, and we’re strongly committed to the mission of ensuring that banks provide credit to their—throughout their communities, particularly addressing the needs of low- and moderate-income households and neighborhoods.

sentence: You know, I don’t know whether that’ll be possible or not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will have to—well, we’ll just have to see, but—and if we—if we can’t, I don’t—I’m not sure what the path forward would be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We would certainly not want to create confusion or, you know, sort of tension between the regimes if they do turn out to be slightly different regimes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s something we—I hope we don’t have to face, but we will if we have to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Really, wages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, we—there’s so many other measures that suggest that the labor market is—I like to say the labor market is strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t really want to say that it’s tight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Someone asked me a question about a hot labor market—that was in the Humphrey-Hawkins hearings.

sentence: So I’ll say that the labor market is strong.

sentence: But the one that has—that is kind of suggesting that you’re—it’s a healthy number that, you know, the sort of 3.1 percent average hourly earnings number is a decent number—3.7 percent for production and nonsupervisory workers is more healthy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Ultimately, though, we’d like to see—to call it “hot,” you’d want to see heat.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
